docs.title: What is r0astr?
docs.text:
r0astr is a multi-instrument live coding interface built on Strudel. Write patterns in code, hear them instantly, and perform live.

  • :material-music-note-multiple: Multiple Instruments

    Four independent cards, each running its own pattern. Drums, bass, melody, ambient – layer them all.

  • Perfect Sync

    All instruments share a clock. Start and stop cards freely – they always stay in time.

  • Live Sliders

    Add slider() to any parameter. Tweak filters, tempo, and effects in real-time.

  • Code as Music

    Write patterns using Strudel's mini notation. Powerful yet beginner-friendly.

docs.title: Pattern Examples
docs.text: A collection of ready-to-use patterns for r0astr. Copy these into your cards and experiment!

docs.title: Basic Four-on-the-Floor
docs.text:
s("bd*4, ~ sd ~ sd, hh*8").gain(0.8)
Classic house/techno beat with kick, snare, and hi-hats.

docs.title: Breakbeat
docs.text:
s("bd ~ bd ~, ~ sd ~ [sd sd], [~ hh]*4").fast(1.5)
A more complex breakbeat pattern with syncopation.

docs.title: Minimal Techno
docs.text:
s("bd ~ ~ ~, ~ ~ sd ~, ~ hh ~ hh").delay(0.125).delayfeedback(0.4)
Sparse techno pattern with delay for movement.

docs.title: Deep Sub Bass
docs.text:
note("c2 ~ c2 ~").s("sawtooth").lpf(slider(400, 100, 1000)).gain(0.6)
Simple but effective sub bass with controllable filter.

docs.title: Funky Bass
docs.text:
note("c2 ~ eb2 f2").s("sawtooth").lpf(600).decay(0.1).fast(2)
More rhythmic bass line with movement.

docs.title: Acid Bass
docs.text:
note("c2 ~ eb2 ~").s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(slider(800, 200, 4000))
  .resonance(10)
  .gain(0.5)
Classic acid sound with resonant filter sweep.

docs.title: Simple Arpeggio
docs.text:
n("0 2 3 5").scale("C4:minor").s("triangle").lpf(600).fast(2)
Basic melodic arpeggio in C minor.

docs.title: Chord Progression
docs.text:
note("<c3'maj7 f3'maj7 g3'7 a3'm7>")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(1000)
  .room(0.5)
  .slow(4)
Jazz-inspired chord progression with reverb.

docs.title: Euclidean Melody
docs.text:
note("c4 d4 e4 g4 a4").euclidean(3, 8).scale("C:minor").s("sine")
Euclidean rhythm applied to melodic notes.

docs.title: Pad
docs.text:
note("c3 e3 g3")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(400)
  .room(0.9)
  .gain(slider(0.3, 0, 0.6))
  .slow(8)
Slow-moving ambient pad with heavy reverb.

docs.title: Drone
docs.text:
note("c2 g2")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(300)
  .room(0.95)
  .delay(0.5)
  .delayfeedback(0.7)
  .gain(0.4)
Deep drone with delay and reverb.

docs.title: Texture
docs.text:
s("~ ~ click ~")
  .speed(rand.range(0.5, 2))
  .room(1)
  .delay(slider(0.3, 0, 0.8))
  .gain(0.3)
Random textural clicks with effects.

docs.text:
Card 1 - Kick: 

s("bd*4").gain(0.9)

Card 2 - Hi-hats: 

s("~ hh ~ hh").delay(0.125).gain(0.6)

Card 3 - Bass:

  .lpf(800)
  .room(0.4)
  .fast(2)

docs.title: Ambient Set (4 Cards)
docs.text:
Card 1 - Low Drone:

Card 2 - Mid Drone:

docs.title: Using Randomness
docs.text:
note("c3 d3 e3 g3").sometimes(x => x.fast(2))
Randomly speeds up the pattern sometimes.

docs.title: Polyrhythms
docs.text:

Three different rhythmic patterns creating complex timing.

docs.title: Degrading
docs.text:

Randomly removes 30% of events for variation.

docs.title: Chopping Patterns
docs.text:

docs.title: Interactive Control Tips
docs.text:
Use sliders for live performance control:

// Wet/dry mix

// Tempo variation

// Filter cutoff
note("c2").lpf(slider(800, 100, 5000))

// Gain/volume
s("bd ~ sd ~").gain(slider(0.7, 0, 1))

docs.title: Your First Pattern
docs.text: Let's make some noise.

docs.title: Step 1: Find Card 1
docs.text: You'll see four cards on screen. Each card is an independent instrument. Find Card 1 (or Panel 1).

docs.title: Step 2: Enter a Pattern
docs.text:
Click in the text area and paste this drum pattern:

s("bd*4, ~ sd ~ sd, hh*8").gain(0.8)

What does this mean?

  • s("...") plays samples (sounds)
  • bd*4 = bass drum 4 times
  • ~ sd ~ sd = snare on beats 2 and 4 (~ is silence)
  • hh*8 = hi-hat 8 times
  • .gain(0.8) = volume at 80%

docs.title: Step 3: Hit Play
docs.text:
Click the Play button on Card 1. You should hear a basic drum beat!

Congratulations!

You just wrote your first live coding pattern.

docs.title: Add a Second Instrument
docs.text: Now let's layer in some bass.

docs.title: Step 1: Find Card 2
docs.text: Leave Card 1 playing. Find Card 2.

docs.title: Step 2: Enter a Bass Pattern
docs.text:
Paste this into Card 2:

note("c2 ~ c2 e2").s("sawtooth").lpf(400).gain(0.6)

What does this mean?

  • note("...") plays synth notes
  • c2, e2 = notes (C and E, octave 2)
  • .s("sawtooth") = sawtooth wave synth
  • .lpf(400) = low-pass filter at 400Hz
  • .gain(0.6) = volume at 60%

docs.title: Step 3: Hit Play on Card 2
docs.text: Click Play. The bass joins the drums – perfectly in sync!

docs.title: Try More Patterns
docs.text: Add these to Cards 3 and 4:

docs.title: Card 3: Melody
docs.text: n("0 2 3 5 3 2").scale("C4:minor").s("triangle").gain(0.5)

docs.title: Card 4: Ambient Pad
docs.text:
n("0 3 7").scale("C3:minor").s("sawtooth").lpf(600).room(0.8).slow(4).gain(0.4)

Now you have a full arrangement with drums, bass, melody, and ambient texture!

  • [x] s() plays samples, note() plays synths
  • [x] All cards share the same clock (they stay in sync)
  • [x] Play/Pause controls each card independently

docs.title: Remote Control
docs.text: Control r0astr from your tablet, phone, or any device on your network.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
r0astr includes a remote control interface that lets you control panels from a secondary device. Perfect for:

  • Using an iPad as a control surface while coding on your laptop
  • Triggering panels from a phone during live performance
  • Controlling r0astr from across the room

docs.title: 1. Start r0astr
docs.text:
Run r0astr on your main computer:

npm run dev

Or launch the desktop app.

docs.title: 2. Find Your IP Address
docs.text:
macOSWindowsLinux

Open Terminal and run:

ipconfig getifaddr en0

Or go to System Settings → Network → Your connection → Details → IP Address

Open Command Prompt and run:

ipconfig

Look for "IPv4 Address" under your active network adapter.

Open Terminal and run:

hostname -I | awk '{print $1}'

docs.title: 3. Connect from Your Device
docs.text:
On your tablet or phone:

  1. Make sure you're on the same WiFi network
  2. Open your browser
  3. Go to: http://YOUR-IP:5173/remote.html

For example: http://192.168.1.100:5173/remote.html

docs.title: Network Requirements
docs.text:
Same Network Required

The remote device MUST be on the same local network as the computer running r0astr.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text: Requirement Details Same WiFi Both devices on the same network Port 5173 Must not be blocked by firewall No VPN VPN can interfere with local connections

docs.title: Guest Networks
docs.text: Most "guest" WiFi networks isolate devices from each other. If you can't connect, try the main network instead.

docs.title: Remote Interface Features
docs.text: The remote interface provides:

docs.title: Panel Controls
docs.text:
• Play/Pause buttons for each panel
  • Visual indicators showing which panels are playing
  • Panel numbering matches the main interface

docs.title: Global Controls
docs.text:
• Stop All - Immediately stops all panels
  • Connection status - Shows if connected to r0astr

docs.title: Auto-Reconnection
docs.text:
If the connection drops:

  1. The interface shows "Disconnected"
  2. Automatically attempts to reconnect
  3. Reconnects when r0astr becomes available again

docs.title: "Disconnected" Status
docs.text:
Cause: Cannot reach the r0astr server.

Solutions:

  1. Verify r0astr is running on your computer
  2. Check you're using the correct IP address
  3. Ensure both devices are on the same WiFi
  4. Try refreshing the remote page

docs.title: Can't Connect Initially
docs.text:
Common issues:

Problem Solution Wrong IP Re-check your computer's IP address Different networks Connect both devices to same WiFi Guest network Use main network instead Firewall blocking Allow port 5173 in firewall settings VPN active Disable VPN on both devices

docs.title: Intermittent Disconnects
docs.text:
Possible causes:

  • Weak WiFi signal
  • Network congestion
  • Sleep/standby modes

Solutions:

  • Move closer to WiFi router
  • Keep devices awake during performance
  • Consider a dedicated WiFi for performances

docs.text: Mistake Correct Approach Using localhost Use your actual network IP (192.168.x.x) Using 127.0.0.1 This only works on the same machine Old IP after network change Re-check IP address after WiFi changes

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
Local Network Only

The remote control is designed for local network use only. Do not expose to the public internet.

docs.title: Current Security Model
docs.text:
• No authentication - Anyone on your network can connect
  • Local only - Only accessible within your network
  • Trust model - Assumes trusted local environment

docs.title: Recommendations
docs.text:
• Use on trusted networks only
  • Avoid public WiFi for performances
  • Consider a dedicated portable router for gigs
  • Keep r0astr updated

docs.title: WebSocket Protocol
docs.text:
For Advanced Users

This section is for developers building custom integrations.

The remote control uses WebSocket for real-time communication.

docs.text: Type Direction Purpose panel:start Client → Server Start a panel panel:stop Client → Server Stop a panel playback:stop-all Client → Server Stop all panels state:get Client → Server Request current state state:current Server → Client Current state response event:panel-state Server → Client Panel state changed

docs.title: Usage Guide
docs.text: Learn how to use r0astr effectively for live coding and music composition.

docs.title: Interface Overview
docs.text:
The r0astr interface consists of:

  • 4 Instrument Cards - Each card is an independent instrument
  • Master Panel - Global controls (if configured)
  • Code Editors - Write your pattern code in each card
  • Play/Pause Buttons - Control each instrument individually

docs.title: Starting a Pattern
docs.text:
1. Write or edit pattern code in a card's textarea
  2. Click the Play button for that card
  3. The pattern starts playing immediately

docs.title: Updating a Pattern
docs.text:
1. Edit the code while the pattern is playing
  2. Click Play again to apply changes
  3. The update happens on the next cycle boundary

docs.title: Pausing a Pattern
docs.text:
• Click Pause to mute that specific instrument
  • Other instruments continue playing
  • The pattern stays synchronized but produces no sound

docs.title: Stopping a Pattern
docs.text:
• Click Stop (if available) to completely stop and reset the pattern
  • Or use Pause to mute without stopping

docs.title: Sounds and Samples
docs.text:
// Play a sample
s("bd")

// Play multiple samples in sequence
s("bd hh sd hh")

// Layer patterns
s("bd*4, ~ sd ~ sd")

docs.title: Notes and Melodies
docs.text:
// Specific notes
note("c3 e3 g3")

// Scale degrees
n("0 2 4").scale("C:minor")

// Chords
note("<c3'maj7 f3'maj7>")

docs.title: Timing and Rhythm
docs.text:
// Multiply pattern (4 kicks per cycle)
s("bd*4")

// Subdivide (hi-hats twice as fast)
s("bd [hh hh]")

// Speed up pattern
s("bd hh sd hh").fast(2)

// Slow down pattern
s("bd hh sd hh").slow(2)

docs.title: Sliders for Interactive Control
docs.text:
Use slider() to create interactive controls:

// Basic slider: slider(default, min, max)
note("c2").lpf(slider(800, 100, 5000))

This creates a slider widget in the UI that you can adjust in real-time!

docs.title: Slider Examples
docs.text:
// Volume control
s("bd*4").gain(slider(0.8, 0, 1))

// Filter sweep
note("c2").lpf(slider(800, 100, 5000))

// Room size (reverb)
s("bd hh sd hh").room(slider(0.5, 0, 1))

// Delay time
s("hh*8").delay(slider(0.25, 0, 0.5))

docs.title: Filters
docs.text:
// Low-pass filter
.lpf(800)

// High-pass filter
.hpf(200)

// Band-pass filter
.bpf(1000)

docs.title: Time-Based Effects
docs.text:
// Reverb (room size)
.room(0.5)

// Delay
.delay(0.25)

// Delay with feedback
.delay(0.25).delayfeedback(0.6)

docs.title: Dynamics
docs.text:
// Volume
.gain(0.8)

// Velocity (for note-based patterns)
.velocity(0.7)

docs.title: Synchronization
docs.text:
All patterns share a common clock:

  • Patterns stay in sync automatically
  • You can start/stop cards independently
  • Timing relationships are maintained

docs.title: Tips for Live Performance
docs.text:
1. Prepare patterns - Write variations before performing
  2. Use sliders - Control parameters in real-time
  3. Layer gradually - Start with drums, add bass, then melody
  4. Mute strategically - Use Pause to create breaks and builds
  5. Remote control - Use an iPad for hands-on control (see Remote Control)

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Quick answers to common questions.

docs.title: What is r0astr?
docs.text: r0astr is a multi-instrument live coding interface built on Strudel. It provides a card-based UI where each card is an independent instrument, all synchronized to a shared clock.

docs.title: Is r0astr free?
docs.text: Yes, r0astr is open source and free to use under the AGPL-3.0 license.

docs.title: What browsers are supported?
docs.text:
• Chrome (recommended)
  • Firefox
  • Safari (macOS 14+)
  • Edge

docs.title: Do I need to install anything?
docs.text: No! You can try r0astr in your browser immediately. For offline use and remote control features, download the desktop app.

docs.title: Why is there no sound?
docs.text: Browsers require user interaction before playing audio. Click anywhere on the page, then try playing your pattern. See Troubleshooting for more help.

docs.title: How do I stop all sounds?
docs.text: Click the Stop All button in the master panel, or use keyboard shortcut (coming soon).

docs.title: Can I use my own samples?
docs.text: Yes! See Custom Samples for instructions.

docs.title: What's the difference between s() and note()?
docs.text:
• s("bd") plays samples (pre-recorded sounds)
  • note("c3") plays synthesizers (generated tones)

docs.title: How do sliders work?
docs.text:
Use slider(default, min, max) in your pattern:

note("c2").lpf(slider(800, 100, 5000))

This creates a control that you can adjust in real-time.

docs.title: How do I set up remote control?
docs.text:
1. Start r0astr on your computer
  2. Find your computer's local IP (e.g., 192.168.1.100)
  3. On your iPad/phone, open http://192.168.1.100:5173/remote.html
  4. Both devices must be on the same WiFi network

See Remote Control for detailed instructions.

docs.title: Why won't my remote connect?
docs.text:
• Ensure both devices are on the same WiFi
  • Check that r0astr is running on your computer
  • Try refreshing the remote page
  • Check your firewall settings

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: r0astr provides WebSocket endpoints for real-time control and integration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The API enables:

  • Remote control of panels (start, stop, update patterns)
  • Playback control (tempo, stop all)
  • State queries (current patterns, playing status)

docs.title: WebSocket Endpoint
docs.text:
ws://[host]:5173/ws

The WebSocket server runs alongside the development server.

docs.title: Message Format
docs.text:
All messages are JSON objects:

{
  "type": "message-type",
  "payload": { ... }
}

docs.title: Start Panel
docs.text:
{
  "type": "panel:start",
  "payload": {
    "panelId": "panel-1"
  }
}

docs.title: Stop Panel
docs.text:
{
  "type": "panel:stop",
  "payload": {
    "panelId": "panel-1"
  }
}

docs.title: Update Pattern
docs.text:
{
  "type": "panel:update",
  "payload": {
    "panelId": "panel-1",
    "pattern": "s(\"bd*4\")"
  }
}

docs.title: Stop All
docs.text:
{
  "type": "playback:stop-all"
}

docs.title: Set Tempo
docs.text:
{
  "type": "playback:tempo",
  "payload": {
    "bpm": 120
  }
}

docs.title: Get State
docs.text:
{
  "type": "state:get"
}

Response: 

{
  "type": "state:current",
  "payload": {
    "panels": [
      {
        "id": "panel-1",
        "playing": true,
        "pattern": "s(\"bd*4\")"
      }
    ],
    "tempo": 120
  }
}

docs.title: Events
docs.text: The server broadcasts state changes:

docs.title: Panel State Changed
docs.text:
{
  "type": "event:panel-state",
  "payload": {
    "panelId": "panel-1",
    "playing": true
  }
}

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Errors are returned as:

{
  "type": "error",
  "payload": {
    "code": "INVALID_PANEL",
    "message": "Panel not found: panel-99"
  }
}

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text: No rate limiting is currently enforced. Be reasonable with message frequency.

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
Local Network Only

The API is designed for local network use. Do not expose to the public internet without additional security measures.

See Remote Control for the built-in remote interface.

docs.title: UI Layer (src/main.js)

docs.title: Strudel Integration
docs.text:
const { evaluate, scheduler } = repl({
  defaultOutput: webaudioOutput,
  getTime: () => ctx.currentTime,
  transpiler,
});

Key integration points:

  • repl() - Creates the pattern evaluation environment
  • evaluate() - Compiles and runs pattern code
  • scheduler - Manages pattern timing and synchronization
  • transpiler - Converts pattern code to executable JavaScript

docs.title: Audio Engine
docs.text:
• Single shared AudioContext (browser requirement)
  • All patterns share the same audio clock
  • Web Audio nodes for synthesis and effects

docs.title: WebSocket Server
docs.text:
• Runs on the Vite dev server
  • Handles remote control connections
  • Broadcasts state changes to all clients

  2. Pattern sent to Strudel transpiler
  3. Transpiler generates executable code
  4. Scheduler evaluates pattern each cycle
  5. Audio output sent to Web Audio API
  6. State changes broadcast via WebSocket

docs.title: Hello World Plugin
docs.text:
A complete working plugin:

// src/index.js
const WebSocket = require('ws');

const R0ASTR_URL = process.env.R0ASTR_URL || 'ws://localhost:5173/ws';

class R0astrPlugin {
  constructor() {
    this.ws = null;
    this.connected = false;
  }

  connect() {
    console.log(`Connecting to r0astr at ${R0ASTR_URL}...`);
    this.ws = new WebSocket(R0ASTR_URL);

    this.ws.on('open', () => {
      console.log('Connected to r0astr!');
      this.connected = true;
      this.onConnected();
    });

    this.ws.on('message', (data) => {
      const message = JSON.parse(data);
      this.onMessage(message);
    });

    this.ws.on('close', () => {
      console.log('Disconnected from r0astr');
      this.connected = false;
      // Attempt reconnect after 5 seconds
      setTimeout(() => this.connect(), 5000);
    });

    this.ws.on('error', (err) => {
      console.error('Connection error:', err.message);
    });
  }

  onConnected() {
    // Request current state on connect
    this.send({ type: 'state:get' });
  }

  onMessage(message) {
    console.log('Received:', message.type);

    switch (message.type) {
      case 'state:current':
        console.log('Current state:', message.payload);
        break;
      case 'event:panel-state':
        console.log('Panel changed:', message.payload);
        break;
    }
  }

  send(message) {
    if (this.connected) {
      this.ws.send(JSON.stringify(message));
    }
  }

  // Panel control methods
  startPanel(panelId) {
    this.send({
      type: 'panel:start',
      payload: { panelId }
    });
  }

  stopPanel(panelId) {
    this.send({
      type: 'panel:stop',
      payload: { panelId }
    });
  }

  updatePattern(panelId, pattern) {
    this.send({
      type: 'panel:update',
      payload: { panelId, pattern }
    });
  }

  stopAll() {
    this.send({ type: 'playback:stop-all' });
  }
}

// Start the plugin
const plugin = new R0astrPlugin();
plugin.connect();

// Example: Start panel 1 after 3 seconds
setTimeout(() => {
  console.log('Starting panel 1...');
  plugin.startPanel('panel-1');
}, 3000);

docs.title: Subscribing to Events
docs.text:
Events are automatically broadcast to all connected clients. Simply handle them in your onMessage handler:

onMessage(message) {
  switch (message.type) {
    case 'event:panel-state':
      this.handlePanelState(message.payload);
      break;
    case 'event:pattern-update':
      this.handlePatternUpdate(message.payload);
      break;
  }
}

Map MIDI CC to sliders, notes to panel triggers:

// ... MIDI setup ...

  const [status, cc, value] = message;

  if (status === 0xB0) { // CC message
    // Map CC to slider value
    const sliderValue = value / 127;
    // Update pattern with new value
  }

  if (status === 0x90) { // Note on
    const panelId = `panel-${(cc % 4) + 1}`;
    plugin.startPanel(panelId);

docs.title: OSC Bridge
docs.text:
Connect to SuperCollider, Max/MSP, TouchOSC:

const osc = require('osc');

const oscPort = new osc.UDPPort({
  localPort: 57121
});

oscPort.on('message', (oscMessage) => {
  if (oscMessage.address === '/r0astr/panel/1/start') {
    plugin.startPanel('panel-1');
  }
});

docs.title: Pattern Sequencer
docs.text:
Programmatically change patterns over time:

const patterns = [
  's("bd*4")',
  's("bd*4, hh*8")',
  's("bd*4, hh*8, ~ sd ~ sd")'
];

let index = 0;

setInterval(() => {
  plugin.updatePattern('panel-1', patterns[index]);
  index = (index + 1) % patterns.length;
}, 4000); // Change every 4 seconds

docs.title: The Big Picture
docs.text:
r0astr is a multi-instrument live coding environment. Think of it as having four independent instruments on stage, all connected to the same metronome. You write code to control each instrument, and they all play together in perfect sync.

docs.title: Cards
docs.text: Each card is an independent instrument in r0astr.

docs.title: What is a Card?
docs.text:
A card is a self-contained unit that includes:

  • A code editor where you write patterns
  • A Play/Pause button to control playback
  • Slider controls for real-time parameter adjustments

docs.title: Independence
docs.text:
Cards operate independently:

  • Different patterns: Each card can play completely different music
  • Separate controls: Start, stop, and modify each card without affecting others
  • Own parameters: Each card can have its own sliders and settings

docs.title: Typical Setup
docs.text:
Most compositions use cards for different roles:

Card Common Use Card 1 Drums and percussion Card 2 Bass line Card 3 Melody or lead Card 4 Ambient or effects

This is just a suggestion - use cards however you like!

Learn more in the Multi-Instrument Guide

docs.title: Synchronization
docs.text: All cards share a single audio clock. This is the key to how r0astr works.

docs.title: Shared Clock
docs.text:
• Every card receives timing from the same master clock
  • When you start a new card, it automatically syncs with already-playing patterns
  • No drift or timing issues between instruments

docs.title: What This Means in Practice
docs.text:
1. Start Card 1 with a drum pattern
  2. Start Card 2 with a bass line - it immediately locks to the beat
  3. Start Card 3 with a melody - also perfectly in sync
  4. All three play together as if they were designed as one piece

docs.title: Quantization
docs.text:
When you press Play on a card:

  • The pattern doesn't start immediately at a random point
  • It waits for the next cycle boundary
  • This ensures musical timing is always correct

docs.title: Master Panel
docs.text: The master panel sits above all cards and provides global controls.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The master panel affects everything at once:

  • TEMPO: Set the speed (in CPS - cycles per second)
  • Global Sliders: Create variables like SLIDER_LPF that all cards can use
  • Master Effects: Apply filters or effects to the entire mix

docs.title: TEMPO Control
docs.text:
The master panel is where you set the global tempo using a slider:

// In Master Panel
let TEMPO = slider(30, 15, 45);  // 30 CPS, range 15-45

All cards automatically follow this tempo.

docs.title: Global Sliders
docs.text:
Define sliders in the master panel that any card can reference:

// Master Panel
let SLIDER_LPF = slider(800, 100, 5000);

// Card 1 (or any card) can use it:
s("bd*4").lpf(SLIDER_LPF)

This lets you control parameters across all instruments with a single slider.

Learn more in the Master Panel Guide

docs.title: Pattern Lifecycle
docs.text: Understanding how patterns work as you edit and play them.

docs.title: Step by Step
docs.text:
1. Write: Type or paste a pattern into a card's text area
  2. Play: Click the Play button to start the pattern
  3. Listen: Audio plays immediately through your speakers
  4. Edit (optional): Modify the pattern while it's playing
  5. Update: Changes take effect on the next cycle
  6. Pause: Click Pause to stop only that card

docs.title: Live Coding
docs.text:
The magic of r0astr is live coding:

  • Edit patterns while they play
  • Hear changes almost instantly
  • No need to stop and restart
  • Experiment in real-time

Pro Tip

Make small changes and listen. This is the essence of live coding - evolving your music incrementally as you play.

docs.title: How They Connect
docs.text:
Let's tie all the concepts together:

  1. You write patterns in each card using Strudel's mini notation
  2. Cards are independent - each runs its own pattern
  3. The master panel provides global controls like TEMPO
  4. A shared clock keeps everything synchronized
  5. Live updates let you evolve your music in real-time

docs.title: Master Panel Guide
docs.text: Learn to control global tempo and create shared parameters across all cards.

docs.title: What is the Master Panel?
docs.text:
The master panel sits above the four cards and provides controls that affect everything at once:

  • TEMPO: Controls the speed of all patterns
  • Global Sliders: Variables that any card can reference
  • Stop All: Stops all cards simultaneously

Think of the master panel as the conductor - it sets the tempo and overall tone, while each card (musician) plays their own part.

docs.title: What TEMPO Does
docs.text: TEMPO controls how fast patterns play across all cards. When you adjust TEMPO, every playing pattern speeds up or slows down together.

docs.title: Default Setup
docs.text:
The master panel includes a TEMPO slider:

let TEMPO = slider(30, 15, 45);
Parameter Value Meaning Default 30 Starting speed Min 15 Slowest setting Max 45 Fastest setting

docs.title: How Speed Works
docs.text:
r0astr uses CPS (Cycles Per Second) internally. You don't need to understand the math - just know that:

  • Higher TEMPO = faster patterns
  • Lower TEMPO = slower patterns
  • All cards follow the same tempo

docs.title: Practical Use
docs.text:
1. Start with the default tempo
  2. Use the slider to find a comfortable speed
  3. All patterns automatically adjust

Performance Tip

Subtle tempo changes during a performance can add dynamics. Try slowly increasing tempo to build energy.

docs.title: Global Effect Sliders
docs.text: Create sliders in the master panel that control parameters across all cards.

docs.title: Why Use Global Sliders?
docs.text:
Instead of adding separate filter sliders to each card, create one in the master panel:

  • Single control affects everything
  • Consistent effect across all instruments
  • Great for sweeps and buildups

docs.title: Creating a Global Slider
docs.text:
In the master panel code:

let SLIDER_LPF = slider(800, 100, 5000);

This creates: - A slider named SLIDER_LPF - Starting at 800 Hz - Range from 100 Hz to 5000 Hz

docs.title: Using in Cards
docs.text:
Reference the variable name in any card:

// Card 1
s("bd*4").lpf(SLIDER_LPF)

// Card 2
note("c2 ~ c2 e2").s("sawtooth").lpf(SLIDER_LPF)

// Card 3
n("0 2 4").scale("C4:minor").s("triangle").lpf(SLIDER_LPF)

Now one slider controls the filter on all three cards.

docs.title: Multiple Global Sliders
docs.text:
Add as many as you need:

// Master Panel
let SLIDER_LPF = slider(800, 100, 5000);
let REVERB = slider(0.3, 0, 1);
let MASTER_GAIN = slider(0.8, 0, 1);

Use them in cards:

note("c2").lpf(SLIDER_LPF).room(REVERB).gain(MASTER_GAIN)

docs.title: Step 1: Define in Master Panel
docs.text:
Write your slider definitions in the master panel:

let FILTER = slider(1000, 200, 4000);
let SPACE = slider(0.5, 0, 1);

docs.title: Step 2: Use in Card Patterns
docs.text:
Reference the variable names (exactly as written) in any card:

// This card uses both global sliders
note("c2 e2 g2")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(FILTER)
  .room(SPACE)
  .gain(0.6)

docs.title: Step 3: Control in Real-Time
docs.text: Adjust the sliders while patterns play. All cards using those variables update instantly.

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text:
Use clear, descriptive names:

Good Why SLIDER_LPF Clear it's a slider, controls low-pass MASTER_GAIN Indicates global volume REVERB Simple and obvious TEMPO Special - controls global speed

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text:
let NAME = slider(default, min, max);
Part Description let NAME Variable name to use in cards slider() Creates a slider control default Starting value min Minimum value max Maximum value

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Filter Control (Hz): 

let FILTER_CUTOFF = slider(800, 100, 8000);

Volume Control (0-1): 

let VOLUME = slider(0.7, 0, 1);

Reverb Amount (0-1): 

let ROOM_SIZE = slider(0.4, 0, 1);

Speed Modifier: 

let SPEED = slider(1, 0.5, 4);

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
Master Panel: 

let TEMPO = slider(30, 15, 45);
let LPF = slider(1200, 100, 4000);
let REVERB = slider(0.3, 0, 0.9);
let MASTER = slider(0.8, 0, 1);

Card using globals: 

note("c2 e2 g2 e2")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(LPF)
  .room(REVERB)
  .gain(MASTER)

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text: The Stop All button immediately stops every playing pattern across all cards.

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
• End of performance: Clean stop
  • Reset: Start fresh
  • Emergency: Something sounds wrong

docs.title: Behavior
docs.text:
When you click Stop All:

  1. All cards stop immediately
  2. Cards remain paused (not reset)
  3. Code in each card is preserved
  4. Click Play on individual cards to restart

docs.title: Advanced: How Master Panel Works
docs.text:
For Advanced Users

This section explains the technical implementation. You don't need to understand this to use r0astr effectively.

docs.title: Parsing Differences
docs.text:
The master panel works differently from cards:

Feature Cards Master Panel Code evaluation Strudel transpiler Regex parsing Pattern execution Yes No Slider detection Automatic Manual parsing

docs.title: Why Regex?
docs.text: The Strudel transpiler can block when used in the master panel context. To avoid this, r0astr parses master panel code with regex to extract slider definitions.

docs.title: TEMPO Special Handling
docs.text:
TEMPO isn't just a variable - it controls the scheduler:

  1. Master panel code defines: let TEMPO = slider(...);
  2. r0astr detects the TEMPO variable
  3. Changes are converted to CPS (cycles per second)
  4. The scheduler's speed is updated: scheduler.setCps(value)

docs.title: Slider Detection Pattern
docs.text:
Master panel sliders must follow this exact format:

let VARIABLE_NAME = slider(default, min, max);

The parser looks for: - let keyword - Variable name (letters, numbers, underscores) - = slider( - Three numeric values

For detailed technical information, see the Architecture documentation.

docs.title: Master Panel Syntax
docs.text:
// Required for tempo control
let TEMPO = slider(30, 15, 45);

// Optional global sliders
let SLIDER_LPF = slider(800, 100, 5000);
let REVERB = slider(0.3, 0, 1);
let GAIN = slider(0.7, 0, 1);

docs.title: Card Usage
docs.text:
// Reference global sliders by name
note("c2").lpf(SLIDER_LPF).room(REVERB).gain(GAIN)

docs.title: Multi-Instrument Guide
docs.text: Learn to use multiple cards together for layered compositions.

docs.title: The Four-Card Setup
docs.text:
r0astr gives you four independent cards. Think of them as four musicians in a band - each plays their own part, but they all follow the same beat.

Card Typical Role Card 1 Drums / Percussion Card 2 Bass Card 3 Melody / Lead Card 4 Ambient / Texture

This is a common setup, but you can use cards however you like.

docs.title: Individual Control
docs.text:
Each card has its own Play/Pause button:

  • Play: Starts the pattern in that card
  • Pause: Stops only that card (others keep playing)

docs.title: What Happens to Other Cards?
docs.text: Nothing. When you start or stop a card, all other cards continue unchanged. This is the key to live performance - you can bring instruments in and out dynamically.

docs.title: Stop All
docs.text: The master panel has a Stop All button that stops every card at once. Use this when you want complete silence or to reset your performance.

docs.title: Synchronization
docs.text: All cards share a single audio clock. This is fundamental to how r0astr works.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. The master panel sets the global tempo
  2. Every card receives timing from this shared clock
  3. When you press Play on a card, it waits for the next cycle boundary
  4. The pattern joins in perfect sync with anything already playing

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
• No drift: Cards never slowly go out of sync
  • Musical timing: New patterns start at musically sensible moments
  • Confidence: You can add/remove instruments knowing they'll stay in time

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text:
1. Press Play on Card 1 (drums) - it starts immediately
  2. Press Play on Card 2 (bass) - it waits for the next cycle, then joins in sync
  3. Both patterns now play together, locked to the same beat
  4. Press Pause on Card 1 - drums stop, bass continues
  5. Press Play on Card 1 - drums rejoin on the next cycle

docs.title: Complementary Pattern Design
docs.text: Design patterns that work together, not against each other.

docs.title: Role of Drums (Card 1)
docs.text:
Drums provide the rhythmic foundation:

  • Establish the groove
  • Define the pulse
  • Use samples: bd, sd, hh, cp
// Simple four-on-floor
s("bd*4, ~ sd ~ sd, hh*8").gain(0.8)

docs.title: Role of Bass (Card 2)
docs.text:
Bass provides the harmonic foundation:

  • Lock with the kick drum
  • Establish the key/root
  • Use low frequencies (lpf keeps it warm)
// Sub bass matching the drums
note("c2 ~ c2 e2").s("sawtooth").lpf(300).gain(0.6)

docs.title: Role of Melody (Card 3)
docs.text:
Melody provides interest and movement:

  • Sit in the mid-to-high frequency range
  • Use scales to stay in key
  • Add motion and variation
// Minor scale melody
n("0 2 3 5 3 2").scale("C4:minor").s("triangle").gain(0.5)

docs.title: Role of Ambient (Card 4)
docs.text:
Ambient provides texture and space:

  • Fill in the background
  • Use reverb and slow patterns
  • Keep volume low to not overwhelm
// Slow evolving pad
n("0 3 7").scale("C3:minor").s("sawtooth").lpf(600).room(0.9).slow(4).gain(0.4)

docs.title: Samples vs Synths
docs.text: Type Best For Example Samples (s()) Drums, percussion, realistic sounds s("bd sd hh") Synths (note()) Bass, melody, pads note("c3 e3")

docs.title: Frequency Separation
docs.text:
Keep your mix clear by separating frequencies:

Role Frequency Range How Bass Low (60-300 Hz) Use .lpf(300) Drums Wide Samples are pre-EQ'd Melody Mid (300-3000 Hz) Use higher octaves (C4, C5) Ambient Variable Use reverb (.room())

docs.title: Matching Sounds to Roles
docs.text:
• Bass: sawtooth or square with low-pass filter
  • Melody: triangle or sawtooth with mid-range filter
  • Pads: sawtooth with heavy reverb and slow patterns

docs.title: Building Up
docs.text:
A classic performance technique:

  1. Start with drums - Establish the groove
  2. Add bass - Lock in the harmonic foundation
  3. Layer melody - Add interest
  4. Finish with ambient - Fill out the sound

docs.title: Creating Dynamics
docs.text:
Use stops for contrast:

  • Drop the bass: Pause Card 2 for 8 bars, then bring it back
  • Drums only: Stop everything except drums for a breakdown
  • Ambient interlude: Stop drums and bass, let ambient breathe

docs.title: Live Variation
docs.text:
While patterns are playing:

  • Edit the pattern code for instant changes
  • Adjust sliders for real-time parameter tweaks
  • Swap out patterns entirely for different sections

docs.title: Full Arrangement Example
docs.text: Here's a complete four-card arrangement. Copy each pattern into its respective card.

docs.title: Card 1: Drums
docs.text:
s("bd*4, ~ sd ~ sd, hh*8")
  .gain(0.8)

Establishes the beat with kick, snare, and hi-hats.

docs.title: Card 2: Bass
docs.text:
note("c2 ~ c2 e2")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(slider(300, 100, 800))
  .gain(0.6)

Sub bass locked to the kick, with a slider for filter sweeps.

docs.title: Card 3: Melody
docs.text:
n("0 2 3 5 3 2")
  .scale("C4:minor")
  .s("triangle")
  .lpf(1200)
  .gain(slider(0.5, 0, 1))

Minor scale melody with volume control.

docs.title: Card 4: Ambient
docs.text:
n("0 3 7")
  .scale("C3:minor")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(600)
  .room(0.9)
  .slow(4)
  .gain(0.4)

Slow chord pad with heavy reverb for atmosphere.

docs.title: How They Work Together
docs.text:
• Key: All patterns use C minor
  • Tempo: All locked to the master panel tempo
  • Frequency: Bass low, melody mid, ambient spread
  • Dynamics: Sliders allow real-time adjustment

docs.title: Performance Walkthrough
docs.text:
Try this sequence:

  1. Start drums (Card 1) - Let it groove for 4 bars
  2. Add bass (Card 2) - Foundation locked in
  3. Add melody (Card 3) - Music takes shape
  4. Add ambient (Card 4) - Full arrangement
  5. Drop melody - Pause Card 3 for tension
  6. Bring melody back - Release
  7. Stop all except ambient - Breakdown
  8. Restart drums - Build back up

docs.title: Pattern Library
docs.text:
A collection of ready-to-use patterns. Copy and paste into any card.

Difficulty Levels:

  • Beginner - Simple, single-concept patterns
  • Intermediate - Combines multiple techniques
  • Advanced - Complex rhythms or generative elements

docs.title: Combining Patterns
docs.text:
• Stay in key: Use the same scale (e.g., C:minor) across cards
  • Frequency separation: Bass low, melody mid, ambient spread
  • Dynamics: Use .gain() sliders for real-time mix control

docs.title: Modifying Patterns
docs.text:
Start with a pattern and experiment:

  • Change .fast(2) to .fast(4) for double speed
  • Swap scales: C:minor to C:major
  • Add effects: .room(0.5) or .delay(0.25)
  • Add sliders: .lpf(slider(800, 100, 4000))

docs.title: Pattern Syntax
docs.text: Learn the mini notation language for writing patterns in r0astr.

docs.title: Mini Notation Basics
docs.text: r0astr uses Strudel's mini notation - a concise language for describing musical sequences.

docs.title: Sequences
docs.text:
Space-separated sounds play one after another within a cycle:

s("bd sd bd sd")  // Four sounds spread across one cycle

docs.title: Rests (Silence)
docs.text:
Use ~ to create silence:

s("bd ~ sd ~")  // Sound, silence, sound, silence

docs.title: Multiplication
docs.text:
Repeat a sound multiple times with *:

s("bd*4")     // Bass drum 4 times per cycle
s("hh*8")     // Hi-hat 8 times per cycle
s("bd*2 sd")  // Two kicks, then one snare

docs.title: Subdivision
docs.text:
Use [] to subdivide time - items inside share the parent's time slot:

s("bd [hh hh]")      // bd gets half, two hh share the other half
s("bd [sd sd sd]")   // bd gets half, three snares share the other half
s("[[bd bd] hh] sd") // Nested subdivision

docs.title: Stacking (Layering)
docs.text:
Use , to play sounds simultaneously:

s("bd*4, ~ sd ~ sd")           // Kick pattern + snare pattern together
s("bd*4, ~ sd ~ sd, hh*8")     // Full drum kit layered

docs.title: Alternation
docs.text:
Use <> to alternate between options each cycle:

s("<bd sd>")           // bd first cycle, sd second cycle
s("<bd sd cp>")        // Cycles through three sounds
note("<c3 e3 g3>")     // Cycles through three notes

docs.title: Samples with s()
docs.text:
Play built-in samples using s():

s("bd hh sd hh")       // Use sample names
s("bd:0 bd:1 bd:2")    // Different variations with :n

Common Sample Names:

Name Sound bd Bass drum / Kick sd Snare drum hh Hi-hat oh Open hi-hat cp Clap rim Rimshot tom Tom ride Ride cymbal

docs.title: Synths with note()
docs.text:
Generate tones using note() with note names:

note("c3 e3 g3")                    // Play notes
note("c3 e3 g3").s("sawtooth")      // Choose synth type
note("c3 e3 g3").s("triangle")      // Different synth

Synth Types:

Type Sound sawtooth Bright, buzzy (good for bass) triangle Soft, flute-like square Hollow, video-game style sine Pure tone, smooth

docs.title: Scales with n()
docs.text:
Use scale degrees instead of note names:

n("0 2 4 5").scale("C:major")       // C D E F
n("0 1 2 3").scale("C:minor")       // C D Eb F
n("0 2 4").scale("A3:minor")        // Am chord

docs.title: Common Modifiers
docs.text: Chain modifiers after your pattern to shape the sound:

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Modifier Description Range Example .gain(n) Volume level 0-1 .gain(0.5) .lpf(hz) Low-pass filter cutoff 20-20000 .lpf(800) .hpf(hz) High-pass filter cutoff 20-20000 .hpf(200) .fast(n) Speed up pattern 0.5-8 .fast(2) .slow(n) Slow down pattern 0.5-8 .slow(2) .room(n) Reverb amount 0-1 .room(0.5) .delay(n) Delay amount 0-1 .delay(0.25) .pan(n) Stereo position -1 to 1 .pan(-0.5)

docs.title: Volume with .gain()
docs.text:
Control volume from 0 (silent) to 1 (full):

s("bd*4").gain(0.8)                // 80% volume
s("hh*8").gain(0.3)                // Quieter hi-hats

docs.title: Filters with .lpf() and .hpf()
docs.text:
Low-pass filter removes high frequencies (makes sound duller):

note("c2").s("sawtooth").lpf(400)  // Dark bass
note("c2").s("sawtooth").lpf(2000) // Brighter bass

High-pass filter removes low frequencies (makes sound thinner):

s("bd*4").hpf(200)                 // Thin kick

docs.title: Speed with .fast() and .slow()
docs.text:
Change pattern speed:

s("bd sd bd sd").fast(2)           // 2x speed (8 hits per cycle)
s("bd sd bd sd").slow(2)           // Half speed (takes 2 cycles)

docs.title: Reverb with .room()
docs.text:
Add space and ambience:

note("c3 e3 g3").room(0.5)         // Medium reverb
note("c3 e3 g3").room(0.9)         // Large hall reverb

docs.title: Sliders
docs.text: Add interactive sliders to control values in real-time.

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text:
slider(default, min, max)
  • default: Starting value
  • min: Minimum value
  • max: Maximum value

docs.title: Usage Example
docs.text:
note("c2 ~ c2 e2").s("sawtooth").lpf(slider(800, 100, 5000))

This creates a slider that: - Starts at 800 Hz - Can be adjusted from 100 Hz to 5000 Hz - Updates the filter in real-time as you drag

docs.title: Multiple Sliders
docs.text:
Each slider appears in the card's control area:

note("c2 ~ c2 e2")
  .s("sawtooth")
  .lpf(slider(800, 100, 5000))
  .gain(slider(0.6, 0, 1))

  .room(0.2)
